meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To provide for the tracing, confiscation and recovery of the proceeds of drug trafficking, to create offences relating to those proceeds or property representing those proceeds, and for incidental or related matters.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—

def.name: Absconded
def.leadIn: absconded (潛逃), in relation to a person, includes absconded for any reason whatsoever, and whether or not, before absconding, the person had been—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: taken into custody; or

paragraph.name: b
a
paragraph.content: any police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any member of the Customs and Excise Service established by section 3 of the Customs and Excise Service Ordinance (Cap. 342); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other person authorized in writing by the Secretary for Justice for the purposes of this Ordinance; (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.def: confiscation order (沒收令) means an order made under section 3(6);
corresponding law (相應的法律) has the same meaning as in section 2(1) of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134);
dangerous drug (毒品) has the same meaning as in section 2(1) of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134);

def.name: Dealing
def.leadIn: dealing (處理), in relation to property referred to in the definition of drug trafficking, section 10(1) or 25, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receiving or acquiring the property;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: disposing of or converting the property;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: bringing into or removing from Hong Kong the property;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: using the property to borrow money, or as security (whether by way of charge, mortgage or pledge or otherwise); (Added 89 of 1995 s. 2)

subsection.def: defendant (被告) means a person against whom proceedings have been instituted for a drug trafficking offence (whether or not he has been convicted of that offence);

def.name: DrugTrafficking
def.leadIn: drug trafficking (販毒) means doing or being concerned in, whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere, any act constituting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a drug trafficking offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence punishable under a corresponding law,

def.continued: and includes dealing, whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere, with any property which in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking; (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 2)

def.name: DrugTraffickingOffence
def.leadIn: drug trafficking offence (販毒罪行) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the offences specified in Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: conspiracy to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inciting another to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: attempting to commit any of those offences;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of any of those offences;

subsection.def: material (物料) includes any book, document or other record in any form whatsoever, and any article or substance; (Replaced 87 of 1997 s. 36)
property (財產) includes both movable and immovable property within the meaning of section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);
Registrar (司法常務官) means the Registrar of the High Court. (Amended 89 of 1995 s.2; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

This Ordinance applies to property whether it is situated in Hong Kong or elsewhere.

References in this Ordinance to offences include a reference to offences committed before the commencement of this Ordinance; but nothing in this Ordinance imposes any duty or confers any power on any court in or in connection with proceedings against a person for a drug trafficking offence instituted before the commencement of this Ordinance.
References in this Ordinance to property received in connection with drug trafficking include a reference to property received both in that connection and in some other connection.
Subsections (7) to (13) shall have effect for the interpretation of this Ordinance.
Property is held by any person if he holds any interest in it.
References to property held by a person include a reference to property vested in his trustee in bankruptcy or in a liquidator.

References to an interest held by a person beneficially in property include, where the property is vested in his trustee in bankruptcy or in a liquidator, a reference to an interest which would be held by him beneficially if the property were not so vested.
Property is transferred by one person to another if the first person transfers or grants to the other any interest in the property.

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings for an offence are instituted in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
aa
paragraph.content: when a person has been arrested for the offence and released on bail or has refused bail; (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when a person is charged with the offence after being taken into custody without a warrant; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: when an indictment is preferred by the direction or with the consent of a judge under section 24A(1)(b) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221),

subsection.continued: and where the application of this subsection would result in there being more than one time for the institution of proceedings, they shall be taken to have been instituted at the earliest of those times.

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings in Hong Kong for an offence are concluded on the occurrence of one of the following events—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the discontinuance of the proceedings whether by entry of a nolle prosequi or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
paragraph.content: the grant of the Chief Executive’s pardon in respect of his conviction for the offence; (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the court sentencing or otherwise dealing with him in respect of his conviction for the offence where the Secretary for Justice either does not apply for a confiscation order, or applies for a confiscation order and the order is not made; or (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 2; L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the satisfaction of a confiscation order made in the proceedings (whether by payment of the amount due under the order or by the defendant serving imprisonment in default).

subsection.name: 12A
subsection.leadIn: An application for a confiscation order made in respect of a defendant where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable is concluded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance or the District Court decides not to make such an order, when it makes that decision; or (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if such an order is made as a result of that application, when the order is satisfied. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 2)

subsection.name: 12B
subsection.leadIn: An application under section 15(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against a defendant is concluded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance decides not to vary that order, when it makes that decision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Court of First Instance varies that order as a result of that application, when the order is satisfied. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An order or verdict (including an order or verdict of acquittal) is subject to appeal or review so long as an appeal, further appeal or review is pending against the order or verdict; and for this purpose an appeal, further appeal or review shall be treated as pending (where one is competent but has not been instituted) until—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the expiration of the time prescribed for instituting the appeal, further appeal or review. (Amended 79 of 1995 s. 50)

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (15), nothing in this Ordinance shall require the disclosure of any items subject to legal privilege within the meaning of section 22. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
Subsection (14) shall not prejudice the operation of sections 20, 21 and 22. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

part.name: P2
part.heading: Confiscation of Proceeds of Drug Trafficking

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in proceedings before the Court of First Instance or the District Court a person is to be sentenced in respect of one or more drug trafficking offences and has not previously been sentenced in respect of his conviction for the offence, or as the case may be, any of the offences concerned; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: proceedings for one or more drug trafficking offences have been instituted against a person but have not been concluded because the person—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: has died; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application is made by or on behalf of the Secretary for Justice for a confiscation order, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, shall act as follows. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 3. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The court shall first—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(i) is applicable—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.leadIn: make such order or orders (other than a confiscation order) in relation to sentence as is appropriate in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned, and such order or orders may be or include any order—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: imposing any fine on the person;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: involving any payment by the person; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: under section 38F or 56 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134), or under section 72, 84A, 102 or 103 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) is applicable, be satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person has died; and

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(B) is applicable, be satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
A
subparagraph.leadIn: a person who is known to be outside Hong Kong and whose exact whereabouts are known—

subparagraph.name: I
II
subparagraph.content: if that person is in custody outside Hong Kong for purposes other than the purposes referred to in sub-sub-paragraph (I), he is in such custody by virtue of conduct which would constitute an indictable offence if it had occurred in Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: III
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings was given to that person in sufficient time to enable him to defend them;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (2A), a person whose exact whereabouts are not known—

subparagraph.name: I
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken to ascertain the person’s whereabouts (including, if appropriate, a step mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of rule 5(1) of Order 65 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A)); and

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings, addressed to that person, has been published in a Chinese language newspaper, and an English language newspaper, circulating generally in Hong Kong; and (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: having regard to all relevant matters before it, the person could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Where subsection (2)(c)(ii)(B) is applicable, and notwithstanding that the court is satisfied as mentioned in that subsection that actions have been taken, the court may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, require that notice of the proceedings mentioned in that subsection be given to the person mentioned in that subsection in such additional manner as the court may direct. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
The court shall then determine whether the person has benefited from drug trafficking.

For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person who has at any time (whether before or after the commencement of this Ordinance) received any payment or other reward in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another has benefited from drug trafficking.
If the court determines that he has so benefited, the court shall determine in accordance with section 6 the amount to be recovered in his case by virtue of this section.

subsection.leadIn: The court shall then, in respect of the offence or offences concerned, order the person to pay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that amount; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a), such proportion of that amount as it thinks fit after taking into account any order or orders provided for or referred to in subsection (2)(a)(ii)(A), (B) or (C) which has or have been made in respect of the person. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person has been convicted of one or more drug trafficking offences;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person has died or absconded before that application has been concluded,

subsection.continued: then that application may still be concluded notwithstanding that death or abscondment, as the case may be. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where subsection (7) is applicable in relation to a person who has died—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (2)(a)(i) shall not apply in relation to the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court shall not make a confiscation order against the person unless it is satisfied that the person has died. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where subsection (7) is applicable in relation to a person who has absconded, the court shall not make a confiscation order against the person unless it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: a person who is known to be outside Hong Kong and whose exact whereabouts are known—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken, but have been unsuccessful, to obtain the return of that person to Hong Kong for the purposes of the proceedings concerned; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings was given to that person in sufficient time to enable him to defend them;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (9A), a person whose exact whereabouts are not known—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: reasonable steps have been taken to ascertain the person’s whereabouts (including, if appropriate, a step mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of rule 5(1) of Order 65 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A)); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: notice of those proceedings, addressed to that person, has been published in a Chinese language newspaper, and an English language newspaper, circulating generally in Hong Kong. (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.name: 9A
subsection.content: Where subsection (9)(b)(ii) is applicable, and notwithstanding that the court is satisfied as mentioned in that subsection that actions have been taken, the court may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, require that notice of the proceedings mentioned in that subsection be given to the person mentioned in that subsection in such additional manner as the court may direct. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
For the purposes of subsection (2)(b)(ii) or (c)(iii), information may be furnished to the court after the person has died or absconded, as the case may be. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

For the purposes of any Ordinance conferring rights of appeal in criminal cases, a confiscation order made against a person shall be deemed to be a sentence passed on that person in respect of the offence or offences concerned and, in the case of any such person who has died (whether before or after the making of such order), his personal representative may act on his behalf for those purposes. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that the standard of proof required to determine any question arising under this Ordinance as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether a person has benefited from drug trafficking; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount to be recovered in his case in pursuance of a confiscation order,

subsection.continued: shall be on the balance of probabilities. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.content: The fact that under subsection (2)(b)(ii) or (c)(iii) the court is satisfied that a person could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned shall not be admissible in evidence in any proceedings for an offence. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that where an application is made for a confiscation order in any case where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) is applicable, the personal representatives of the deceased person concerned shall, for the purposes of opposing the application, be entitled to be heard on the application and to call, examine and cross-examine any witness. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the commencement of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 (89 of 1995), proceedings for one or more drug trafficking offences have been instituted against a person but have not been concluded because that person has absconded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: immediately before that commencement, any realisable property of that person is the subject of a charging order or restraint order,

subsection.continued: then the provisions of this Ordinance as amended by that Ordinance shall apply in relation to that person as they would apply in relation to a person against whom, on or after that commencement, proceedings for one or more drug trafficking offences have been instituted but have not been concluded because that last-mentioned person has absconded. (Added 89 of 1995 s.3)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: before the commencement of the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) (Amendment) Ordinance 1995 (89 of 1995)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person has been convicted of one or more drug trafficking offences;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the person; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the person has absconded before that application has been concluded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: immediately before that commencement, any realisable property of that person is the subject of a charging order or restraint order,

subsection.continued: then the provisions of this Ordinance as amended by that Ordinance shall apply in relation to that person as they would apply in relation to a person to whom subsection (7) is applicable because he has absconded. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 3)

subsection.content: Where subsection (1)(a)(ii)(A) or (B) is applicable, the reference in that subsection to one or more drug trafficking offences includes any offence previously specified in Schedule 1, and the other provisions of this section and this Ordinance (including paragraphs (b) to (e) of the definition of drug trafficking offence in section 2(1) and any subsidiary legislation) shall be construed accordingly. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

section.name: s4
section.heading: Assessing the proceeds of drug trafficking

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a person’s proceeds of drug trafficking are—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any payments or other rewards received by him at any time (whether before or after 1 December 1989) in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any property derived or realised, directly or indirectly, by him from any of the payments or other rewards; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any pecuniary advantage obtained in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the value of the person’s proceeds of drug trafficking is the aggregate of the values of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the payments or other rewards;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that property; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that pecuniary advantage. (Replaced 87 of 1997 s. 36)

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, may, for the purpose of determining whether the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking and, if he has, of assessing the value of his proceeds of drug trafficking, make the following assumptions, except to the extent that the defendant (or, in the case of a defendant who has died, his personal representative on his behalf) shows that any of the assumptions are incorrect in his case. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 4; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Those assumptions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that any property appearing to the court—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: to have been held by him at any time—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: since his conviction; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, since the application was made for a confiscation order in his case,

subparagraph.continued: as the case may be; or (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 4)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to have been transferred to him at any time since the beginning of the period of 6 years ending when the proceedings were instituted against him,

paragraph.continued: was received by him, at the earliest time at which he appears to the court to have held it, as his proceeds of drug trafficking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that any expenditure of his since the beginning of that period was met out of his proceeds of drug trafficking; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that, for the purpose of valuing any property received or assumed to have been received by him at any time as his proceeds of drug trafficking, he received the property free of any other interests in it. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 4)

subsection.content: For the purpose of assessing the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking in a case where a confiscation order, or an order under section 8(7) of the Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 455), has previously been made against him, the court shall leave out of account any of his proceeds of drug trafficking that are shown to the court to have been taken into account in determining the amount to be recovered under that order. (Amended 82 of 1994 s. 36)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Statements relating to proceeds of drug trafficking

subsection.leadIn: Where an application is made for a confiscation order, the prosecutor may tender to the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, a statement of matters relevant to any of the following— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, determining whether the defendant could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determining whether the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: assessing the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Where any statement has been tendered under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prosecutor may at any time tender to the court a further such statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court may at any time require the prosecutor to tender to it a further such statement within such period as it may direct. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: Where any statement has been tendered under subsection (1) and the court is satisfied that a copy of the statement has been served on the defendant, it may require the defendant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to indicate to it, within such period as it may direct, the extent to which he accepts each allegation in the statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so far as he does not accept any such allegation, to give particulars of any matters on which he proposes to rely. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: Where the court has given a direction under this section, it may at any time vary it by giving a further direction. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Where the defendant accepts to any extent any allegation in any statement tendered under subsection (1), the court may, for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, determining whether the defendant could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determining whether the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: assessing the value of his proceeds of drug trafficking,

subsection.continued: treat his acceptance as conclusive of the matters to which the allegation relates. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: If the defendant fails in any respect to comply with a requirement under subsection (1B) he may be treated for the purposes of this section as accepting every allegation in the statement apart from— (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any allegation in respect of which he has complied with the requirement; (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, any allegation that he could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned; (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any allegation that he has benefited from drug trafficking; and (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any allegation that any payment or other reward was received by him in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant tenders to the court a statement as to any matters relevant to determining the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prosecutor accepts to any extent any allegation in the statement,

subsection.continued: the court may, for the purposes of that determination, treat the acceptance by the prosecutor as conclusive of the matters to which the acceptance relates.

subsection.content: An allegation may be accepted, or particulars of any matter may be given, for the purposes of this section in writing in a form acceptable to the court. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: No acceptance by the defendant under this section that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, he could have been convicted in respect of the offence, or as the case may be, the offences concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any payment or other reward was received by him in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another,

subsection.continued: shall be admissible in evidence in any proceedings for an offence. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings on an application made for a confiscation order where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the defendant has died, subsection (1B) shall have effect as if it required a copy of the statement tendered under subsection (1) to be served on the defendant’s personal representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the defendant has absconded and section 3(2)(c)(ii)(A) or (9)(b)(i) is not applicable to him, this section shall have effect as if a copy of the statement tendered under subsection (1) had been served on the defendant. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that, where section 3(1)(a)(ii) is applicable, this section shall not prejudice the generality of section 3(10). (Added 89 of 1995 s. 5)

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that an allegation may be accepted under this section, and may always have been so accepted, whether or not subsection (7)(a) or (b) is applicable to the defendant, and subsection (3) shall be construed accordingly. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Amount to be recovered under confiscation order

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), the amount to be recovered in the defendant’s case under the confiscation order shall be the amount the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, assesses to be the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

If the court is satisfied as to any matter relevant for determining the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made (whether by an acceptance under section 5 or otherwise), the court may issue a certificate giving the court’s opinion as to the matters concerned and shall do so if satisfied as mentioned in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: If the court is satisfied that the amount that might be realised at the time the confiscation order is made is less than the amount the court assesses to be the value of his proceeds of drug trafficking, the amount to be recovered in the defendant’s case under the confiscation order shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount appearing to the court to be so realised; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a nominal amount, where it appears to the court (on the information available to it at the time) that the amount that might be so realised is nil. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 6)

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Interest on amounts to be recovered under confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: The amount to be recovered under a confiscation order shall be treated as a judgment debt for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the order was made by the Court of First Instance, section 49 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4); (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the order was made by the District Court, section 50 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336),

subsection.continued: and, for those purposes, the date of the confiscation order shall be treated as the date of the judgment debt.

subsection.content: Where by virtue of subsection (1) any interest accrues on the amount to be recovered under a confiscation order, the defendant shall be liable to pay that interest and the amount of the interest shall for the purposes of enforcement be treated as part of the amount to be recovered from him under the confiscation order.

def.name: RealisableProperty
def.leadIn: In this Ordinance, realisable property (可變現財產) means, subject to subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any property held by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance; and (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any property that is subject to the effective control of the defendant. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.leadIn: Property is not realisable property if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 102 or 103 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 38F or 56 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134),

subsection.continued: is in force in respect of the property.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance the amount that might be realised at the time a confiscation order is made against the defendant is— (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total of the values at that time of all the realisable property held by the defendant, less

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where there are obligations having priority at that time, the total amounts payable in pursuance of such obligations,

subsection.continued: together with the total of the values at that time of all gifts caught by this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the following subsections, for the purposes of this Ordinance the value of property (other than cash) in relation to any person holding the property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where any other person holds an interest in the property, is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the market value of the first mentioned person’s beneficial interest in the property, less

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the amount required to discharge any incumbrance (other than a charging order) on that interest; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, is its market value.

def.name: TheMaterialTime
def.leadIn: Subject to subsection (10), references in this Ordinance to the value at any time (referred to in subsection (6) as the material time (關鍵時間)) of a gift caught by this Ordinance or of any payment or reward are references to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the gift, payment or reward to the recipient when he received it adjusted to take account of subsequent changes in the value of money; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where subsection (6) applies, the value there mentioned,

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (10), if at the material time the recipient holds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the property which he received (not being cash); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: property which, in whole or in part, directly or indirectly represents in his hands the property which he received,

subsection.continued: the value referred to in subsection (5)(b) is the value to him at the material time of the property mentioned in paragraph (a) or, as the case may be, of the property mentioned in paragraph (b) so far as it so represents the property which he received, but disregarding in either case any charging order.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3), an obligation has priority at any time if it is an obligation of the defendant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pay an amount due in respect of a fine, or other order of a court, imposed or made on conviction of an offence, where the fine was imposed or order made before the confiscation order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pay any sum which, if the defendant had been adjudged bankrupt or was being wound up, would be among the preferential debts.

def.name: ThePreferentialDebts
def.leadIn: In subsection (7)(b) the preferential debts (優先債項)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to bankruptcy, means the debts to be paid in priority under section 38 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) (assuming the date of the confiscation order to be the date of filing of the petition and of the bankruptcy order made under that Ordinance); and (Amended 37 of 1998 s. 8)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to winding up, means the debts to be paid under section 265 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) (assuming the date of the confiscation order to be the date of commencement of the winding up and the relevant date for the purpose of that section). (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.leadIn: A gift (including a gift made before the commencement of this Ordinance) is caught by this Ordinance if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it was made by the defendant at any time since the beginning of the period of 6 years ending when the proceedings were instituted against him; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it was made by the defendant at any time and was a gift of property—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: received by the defendant in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: which in whole or in part directly or indirectly represented in the defendant’s hands property received by him in that connection.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the defendant is to be treated as making a gift include those where he transfers property to another person directly or indirectly for a consideration the value of which is significantly less than the value of the consideration provided by the defendant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in those circumstances, the preceding provisions of this section shall apply as if the defendant had made a gift of such share in the property as bears to the whole property the same proportion as the difference between the values referred to in paragraph (a) bears to the value of the consideration provided by the defendant.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: property, or an interest in property, may be subject to the effective control of the defendant whether or not the defendant has—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a legal or equitable estate or interest in the property; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a right, power or privilege in connection with the property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: without limiting the generality of any other provision of this Ordinance, in determining—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether or not property, or an interest in property, is subject to the effective control of the defendant; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether or not there are reasonable grounds to believe that property, or an interest in property, is subject to the effective control of the defendant,

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: shareholdings in, debentures over or directorships of a company that has an interest (whether direct or indirect) in the property;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a trust that has a relationship to the property; and

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: family, domestic and business relationships between persons having an interest in the property, or in companies of the kind referred to in subparagraph (A) or trusts of the kind referred to in subparagraph (B), and other persons. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 8)

subsection.content: Where a person obtains a pecuniary advantage in connection with drug trafficking carried on by him or another, he is to be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as if he had obtained in connection with that drug trafficking a sum of money equal to the value of the advantage, and the other provisions of this Ordinance shall be construed accordingly. (Added 87 of 1997 s.36)

section.name: s8
section.heading: Application of procedure for enforcing confiscation orders

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this section, where the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, makes a confiscation order— (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 9; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the court shall also make an order—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: fixing a term of imprisonment which the defendant is to serve if any of that amount is not duly paid within that period (including paid by way of being recovered); and (Replaced 26 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: section 114(1), (3), (4), (5), (6) and (7) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall apply as if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that amount were a fine imposed upon him by the court; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the term of imprisonment fixed under this section were a term fixed under section 114(1)(c) of that Ordinance.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The court shall not under subsection (1)(a)(i) fix a period longer than 6 months unless it is satisfied that there are special circumstances which justify it doing so. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
The terms set out in the second column of the following table shall be the maximum terms of imprisonment under subsection (1) applicable respectively to the amounts set out opposite thereto.

tr.td: An amount exceeding $200,000 but not exceeding $500,000
An amount exceeding $500,000 but not exceeding $1 million
An amount exceeding $1 million but not exceeding $2.5 million
An amount exceeding $2.5 million but not exceeding $10 million

subsection.content: Subsections (1) and (2) shall apply in relation to the District Court. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 9)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that no limitation on the jurisdiction of the District Court as to the imposition of penalties set out in section 82 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) shall be construed so as to prejudice the operation of subsection (3). (Added 89 of 1995 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: Where the defendant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: becomes liable to serve a term of imprisonment fixed under this section in respect of a confiscation order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is also liable to serve a term of imprisonment or detention in respect of the offence or offences concerned,

subsection.continued: the term of imprisonment mentioned in paragraph (a) shall not begin to run until after the end of the term of imprisonment or detention mentioned in paragraph (b).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: consecutive terms and terms which are wholly or partly concurrent shall be treated as a single term; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: there shall be disregarded—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any sentence suspended under section 109B of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) which has not taken effect at the time the defendant becomes liable to a term of imprisonment under this section; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any term of imprisonment fixed under section 114(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) for which the defendant has not at that time been committed.

subsection.content: Sections 86 and 109A of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall not apply in relation to fixing a term of imprisonment under this section. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 9)
This section shall not apply in relation to a confiscation order where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 9)

At the end of each day’s sitting of the Court of First Instance or the District Court, the Registrar of the High Court or District Court, as the case may be, shall deliver (or cause to be delivered) to the Commissioner of Correctional Services a certificate, in the form specified in Schedule 3, in respect of each term of imprisonment fixed under this section. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 9. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

A certificate referred to in subsection (8) shall be a sufficient warrant to the Commissioner of Correctional Services for receiving into his custody the defendant named in the certificate and for carrying into effect the term of imprisonment fixed under this section in respect of that defendant. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 9)

section.name: s9
section.heading: Cases in which restraint orders and charging orders may be made

subsection.leadIn: The powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10(1) and 11(1) are exercisable where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings have been instituted in Hong Kong against the defendant for a drug trafficking offence or—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the defendant where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an application has been made under section 15(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the defendant; (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proceedings have not, or the application has not, as the case may be, been concluded; (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 10. Amended 26 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (1A), if section 2(11)(aa) is applicable to an offence, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that, in all the circumstances of the case, there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may be charged with the offence after further investigation is carried out; and (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Court of First Instance is satisfied that there is reasonable cause to believe—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: in any other case, that the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 10)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (1B), where a power conferred on the Court of First Instance by section 10(1) or 11(1) is exercisable only on the ground mentioned in subsection (1)(ba), then the Court of First Instance shall specify a date on which any restraint order or charging order arising from that ground shall expire, being a date—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), not later than is reasonably necessary for the purposes of the investigation concerned mentioned in subsection (1)(ba); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any case, not later than 6 months after the date on which that order is made. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may extend a restraint order or charging order mentioned in subsection (1A)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the ground only that the Court of First Instance is satisfied that the defendant will be charged with the offence concerned after further investigation is carried out;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), not longer than is reasonably necessary for the purposes of that investigation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any case, for not more than 6 months. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Those powers are also exercisable where the Court of First Instance is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that whether by the laying of an information or otherwise, a person is to be charged in Hong Kong with a drug trafficking offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there is reasonable cause to believe that he has benefited from drug trafficking.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 10 and 11, in relation to the exercise of those powers at any time before proceedings have been instituted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: references in this Ordinance to the defendant shall be construed as references to the person referred to in subsection (2)(a);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: references in this Ordinance to the prosecutor shall be construed as references to the person who the Court of First Instance is satisfied is to have the conduct of the case for the prosecution in the proposed proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: references in this Ordinance to realisable property shall be construed as if, immediately before that time, proceedings had been instituted against the person referred to in subsection (2)(a) for a drug trafficking offence.

subsection.content: Where the Court of First Instance has made an order under section 10(1) or 11(1) by virtue of subsection (2), the Court of First Instance shall discharge the order if proceedings in respect of the offence are not instituted within such time as the Court of First Instance considers reasonable.

The Court of First Instance may by order (in this Ordinance referred to as a restraint order (限制令)) prohibit any person from dealing with any realisable property, subject to such conditions and exceptions as may be specified in the order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order may apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to all realisable property held by a specified person, whether the property is described in the order or not; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to realisable property held by a specified person, being property transferred to him after the making of the order.

subsection.content: This section shall not have effect in relation to any property for the time being subject to a charge under section 11.

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be made only on an application by the prosecutor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on an ex parte application to a judge in chambers; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall provide for notice to be given to persons affected by the order.

subsection.leadIn: A restraint order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be discharged or varied in relation to any property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be discharged on the conclusion of the proceedings or application concerned. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 11)

subsection.content: An application for the discharge or variation of a restraint order may be made by any person affected by it.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court of First Instance has made a restraint order, the Court of First Instance may at any time appoint a receiver—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take possession of any realisable property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in accordance with the directions of the Court of First Instance, to manage or otherwise deal with any property in respect of which he is appointed,

subsection.continued: subject to such exceptions and conditions as may be specified by the Court of First Instance; and may require any person having possession of property in respect of which a receiver is appointed under this section to give possession of it to the receiver. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Where the Court of First Instance has made a restraint order, an authorized officer may, for the purpose of preventing any realisable property being removed from Hong Kong, seize the property. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
Property seized under subsection (9) shall be dealt with in accordance with the directions of the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Where any property specified in a restraint order is immovable property the order shall, for the purposes of the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be deemed to be an instrument affecting land; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be registrable as such in the Land Registry under that Ordinance in such manner as the Land Registrar thinks fit. (Amended 8 of 1993 ss. 2 & 3)

subsection.content: An authorized officer may, by notice in writing served on a person who holds any realisable property the subject of a restraint order, require the person to deliver to the authorized officer, to the extent that it is practicable to do so, documents, or copies of documents, or any other information (in whatever form), in his possession or control which may assist the authorized officer to determine the value of the property. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

A person who receives a notice under subsection (12) shall, as soon as is practicable after receipt of the notice, comply with the notice to the extent that it is practicable to do so taking into account the nature of the realisable property the subject of the restraint order concerned. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure made in order to comply with a requirement under subsection (12)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (13) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
A person who knowingly deals in any realisable property in contravention of a restraint order commits an offence. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (16) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 or to the value of the realisable property the subject of the restraint order concerned which has been dealt with in contravention of that order, whichever is the greater, and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

section.name: s11
section.heading: Charging orders in respect of land, securities, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may make a charging order on realisable property for securing the payment to the Government—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where a confiscation order has not been made, of an amount equal to the value from time to time of the property charged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, of an amount not exceeding the amount payable under the confiscation order.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a charging order is an order made under this section imposing on any such realisable property as may be specified in the order a charge for securing the payment of money to the Government.

subsection.leadIn: A charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be made only on an application by the prosecutor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on an ex parte application to a judge in chambers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: shall provide for notice to be given to persons affected by the order; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may be made subject to such conditions as the Court of First Instance thinks fit and, without prejudice to the generality of this paragraph, such conditions as it thinks fit as to the time when the charge is to become effective.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), a charge may be imposed by a charging order only on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any interest in realisable property, being an interest held beneficially by the defendant or by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in any asset of a kind specified in Schedule 2; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under any trust; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any interest in realisable property held by a person as trustee of a trust if the interest is in such an asset or is an interest under another trust and a charge may by virtue of paragraph (a) be imposed by a charging order on the whole beneficial interest under the first mentioned trust.

subsection.content: In any case where a charge is imposed by a charging order on any interest in an asset of a kind specified in Schedule 2, the Court of First Instance may provide for the charge to extend to any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of the asset.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to a charging order, the Court of First Instance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make an order discharging or varying it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall make an order discharging the charging order—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on the conclusion of the proceedings or application concerned; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on payment into the Court of First Instance of the amount payment of which is secured by the charge. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 12)

subsection.content: An application for the discharge or variation of a charging order may be made by any person affected by it.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, a charge imposed by a charging order shall have the like effect and shall be enforceable in the same manner as an equitable charge created by the person holding the beneficial interest or, as the case may be, the trustee, by writing under his hand.

An authorized officer may, by notice in writing served on a person who holds any realisable property the subject of a charging order, require the person to deliver to the authorized officer, to the extent that it is practicable to do so, documents, or copies of documents, or any other information (in whatever form), in his possession or control which may assist the authorized officer to determine the value of the property. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

A person who receives a notice under subsection (9) shall, as soon as is practicable after receipt of the notice, comply with the notice to the extent that it is practicable to do so taking into account the nature of the realisable property the subject of the charging order concerned. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure made in order to comply with a requirement under subsection (9)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (10) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)
A person who knowingly deals in any realisable property in contravention of a charging order commits an offence. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (13) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 or to the value of the realisable property the subject of the charging order concerned which has been dealt with in contravention of that order, whichever is the greater, and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Added 26 of 2002 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in proceedings instituted for a drug trafficking offence, a confiscation order is made (including any case where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable); (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 13)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the order is not subject to appeal or review within the meaning of section 2(13); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proceedings have not been concluded,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on an application by the prosecutor, exercise the powers conferred by subsections (2) to (6).

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may appoint a receiver in respect of realisable property.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may empower a receiver appointed under subsection (2), under section 10 or in pursuance of a charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce any charge imposed under section 11 on realisable property or on any interest, dividend or other distribution payable and any bonus issue in respect of such property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to any realisable property other than property for the time being subject to a charge under section 11, to take possession of the property subject to such conditions or exceptions as may be specified by the Court of First Instance.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may order any person having possession of realisable property to give possession of it to any such receiver.
The Court of First Instance may empower any such receiver to realise any realisable property in such manner as the Court of First Instance may direct.

The Court of First Instance may order any person holding an interest in realisable property to make such payment to the receiver in respect of any beneficial interest held by the defendant or, as the case may be, the recipient of a gift caught by this Ordinance as the Court of First Instance may direct and the Court of First Instance may, on the payment being made, by order transfer, grant or extinguish any interest in the property.
Subsections (4) to (6) do not apply to property for the time being subject to a charge under section 11.

The Court of First Instance shall not in respect of any property exercise the powers conferred by subsection (3)(a), (5) or (6) unless a reasonable opportunity has been given for persons holding any interest in the property to make representations to the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Application of proceeds of realisation and other sums

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the following sums in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order, that is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proceeds of the enforcement of any charge imposed under section 11;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any other sums, being property held by the defendant,

subsection.continued: shall first be applied in payment of such expenses incurred by a person acting as an insolvency officer as are payable under section 18(2) and then shall, after such payments (if any) as the Court of First Instance may direct have been made out of those sums— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: be payable to the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: be applied on the defendant’s behalf towards the satisfaction of the confiscation order in the manner provided by subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: If, after the amount payable under the confiscation order has been fully paid, any such sums remain in the hands of such a receiver, the receiver shall distribute those sums—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: among such of those who held property which has been realised under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in such proportions,

subsection.continued: as the Court of First Instance may direct after giving a reasonable opportunity for such persons to make representations to the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: The receipt of any sum by the Registrar on account of an amount payable under a confiscation order shall reduce the amount so payable, but the Registrar shall apply the sum received for the purposes specified in this section and in the order so specified.
The Registrar shall first pay any expenses incurred by a person acting as an insolvency officer and payable under section 18(2) but not already paid under subsection (1).
If the sum was paid to the Registrar by a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order the Registrar shall next pay the receiver’s remuneration and expenses.

subsection.leadIn: After making—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any payment required by subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a case to which subsection (5) applies, any payment required by that subsection,

subsection.continued: the Registrar shall reimburse any amount paid under section 19(2).

subsection.content: Any balance in the hands of the Registrar after he has made all payments required by the foregoing subsections shall be paid into the general revenue. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 14)

section.name: s14
section.heading: Exercise of powers by Court of First Instance or receiver

subsection.content: The following subsections apply to the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 13, or on a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

Subject to subsections (3), (4), (5) and (6), the powers shall be exercised with a view to making available for satisfying the confiscation order or, as the case may be, any confiscation order that may be made in the defendant’s case the value for the time being of realisable property held by any person by the realisation of such property.

In the case of realisable property held by a person to whom the defendant has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance, the powers shall be exercised with a view to realising no more than the value for the time being of the gift.
The powers shall be exercised with a view to allowing any person other than the defendant or the recipient of any such gift to retain or recover the value of any property held by him.
An order may be made or other action taken in respect of a debt owed by the Government.
In exercising those powers, no account shall be taken of any obligations of the defendant or of the recipient of any such gift which conflict with the obligation to satisfy the confiscation order.

subsection.leadIn: If, on an application by the prosecutor or the defendant (or, in the case of a defendant who has died, his personal representative on his behalf) in respect of a confiscation order, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that the realisable property is inadequate for the payment of any amount remaining to be recovered under the confiscation order, the Court of First Instance shall make an order— (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 15)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substituting for the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order such lesser amount as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substituting for the term of imprisonment fixed under section 8 in respect of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order a shorter term determined in accordance with that section in respect of the lesser amount.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: If, on an application by the prosecutor made in respect of a confiscation order, the Court of First Instance is satisfied that any of the conditions referred to in subsection (1B) are fulfilled, the Court of First Instance may make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substituting for the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order such greater amount as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substituting for the term of imprisonment fixed under section 8 in respect of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order a greater term determined in accordance with that section in respect of the greater amount. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 15)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (1A) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking was greater than the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking assessed by the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, at the time of the making of the confiscation order;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the amount realised from the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking is greater than the amount the Court of First Instance or the District Court, as the case may be, assessed to be the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 15)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section— (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 15)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of realisable property held by a person who has been adjudged bankrupt or whose estate has been sequestrated the Court of First Instance shall take into account the extent to which any property held by him may be distributed among creditors; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance may disregard any inadequacy in the realisable property which appears to the Court of First Instance to be attributable wholly or partly to anything done by the defendant for the purpose of preserving any property held by a person to whom the defendant had directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance from any risk of realisation under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: No application shall be entertained by the Court of First Instance under subsection (1A) if it is made after the end of the period of 6 years beginning with the date on which the confiscation order concerned was made. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 15)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who holds realisable property is adjudged bankrupt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: property for the time being subject to a restraint order made before the order adjudging him bankrupt; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceeds of property realised by virtue of section 10(7) or 12(5) or (6) for the time being in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12,

subsection.continued: are excluded from the property of the bankrupt for the purposes of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6).

subsection.leadIn: Where a person has been adjudged bankrupt, the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 13 shall not be exercised in relation to— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: property which is to be applied for the benefit of creditors of the bankrupt by virtue of a condition imposed under section 30A(9) of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6). (Amended 76 of 1996 s. 87)

subsection.content: Nothing in the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) shall be taken as restricting, or enabling the restriction of, the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 13. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not affect the enforcement of a charging order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made before the order adjudging the person bankrupt; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on property which was subject to a restraint order when the order adjudging him bankrupt was made.

subsection.content: Where, in the case of a debtor, an interim trustee stands appointed under section 13 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) and any property of the debtor is subject to a restraint order, the powers conferred on the interim trustee by virtue of that Ordinance do not apply to property for the time being subject to the restraint order. (Amended 18 of 2005 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is adjudged bankrupt and has directly or indirectly made a gift caught by this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a court shall not make an order under—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: section 49 or 50 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Amended 76 of 1996 s. 87)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: section 60 of the Conveyancing and Property Ordinance (Cap. 219),

paragraph.continued: in respect of the making of a gift at any time when—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: proceedings for a drug trafficking offence have been instituted against him but have not been concluded;

subparagraph.name: B
I
subparagraph.content: for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the person where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: has been made under section 15(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the person,

subparagraph.continued: and the application has not been concluded; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: property of the person to whom the gift was made is subject to a restraint order or charging order; and (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 16)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any order made under any of the sections referred to in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) after the conclusion of the proceedings or application shall take into account any realisation under this Ordinance of property held by the person to whom the gift was made. (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 16)

section.name: s17
section.heading: Winding up of company holding realisable property

subsection.leadIn: Where realisable property is held by a company and an order for the winding up of the company has been made or a resolution has been passed by the company for voluntary winding up, the functions of the liquidator (or any provisional liquidator) shall not be exercisable in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: property for the time being subject to a restraint order made before the relevant time; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceeds of property realised by virtue of section 10(7) or 12(5) or (6) for the time being in the hands of a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12.

subsection.leadIn: Where, in the case of a company, such an order has been made or such a resolution has been passed, the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 13 shall not be exercised in relation to any realisable property held by the company in relation to which the functions of the liquidator are exercisable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: so as to inhibit him from exercising those functions for the purpose of distributing any property held by the company to the company’s creditors; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so as to prevent the payment out of any property of expenses (including the remuneration of the liquidator or any provisional liquidator) properly incurred in the winding up in respect of the property.

subsection.content: Nothing in the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) or the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) shall be taken as restricting, or enabling the restriction of, the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 13. (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Subsection (3) shall apply to any proceedings relating to an appeal, further appeal or review against any exercise of the powers referred to in that subsection as if the court hearing the appeal, further appeal or review, as the case may be, were the Court of First Instance. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 17)
Subsection (2) does not affect the enforcement of a charging order made before the relevant time or on property which was subject to a restraint order at the relevant time.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: company (公司) means any company which may be wound up under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

def.name: TheRelevantTime
def.leadIn: the relevant time (有關時間) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where no order for the winding up of the company has been made, the time of the passing of the resolution for voluntary winding up;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where such an order has been made and, before the presentation of the petition for the winding up of the company by the Court of First Instance, such a resolution had been passed by the company, the time of the passing of the resolution; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other case where such an order has been made, the time of the making of the order.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Insolvency officers dealing with property subject to restraint order

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of any provision contained in the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6), the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) or any other Ordinance, where— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any insolvency officer seizes or disposes of any property in relation to which his functions are not exercisable because it is for the time being subject to a restraint order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the time of the seizure or disposal he believes, and has reasonable grounds for believing, that he is entitled (whether in pursuance of an order of a court or otherwise) to seize or dispose of that property,

subsection.continued: he shall not be liable to any other person in respect of any loss or damage resulting from the seizure or disposal except in so far as the loss or damage is caused by his negligence; and the insolvency officer shall have a lien on the property, or the proceeds of its sale, for such of his expenses as were incurred in connection with the liquidation, bankruptcy or other proceedings in relation to which the seizure or disposal purported to take place and for so much of his remuneration as may reasonably be assigned for his acting in connection with those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Any insolvency officer who incurs expenses—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of such property as is mentioned in subsection (1)(a) and in so doing does not know and has no reasonable grounds to believe that the property is for the time being subject to a restraint order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other than in respect of such property as is so mentioned, being expenses which, but for the effect of a restraint order, might have been met by taking possession of and realising the property,

subsection.continued: shall be entitled (whether or not he has seized or disposed of that property so as to have a lien under that subsection) to payment of those expenses under section 13(1) or (3).

def.name: InsolvencyOfficer
def.leadIn: In this section insolvency officer (債務處理人) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Official Receiver; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting as—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a trustee (including provisional trustee), interim trustee or special manager appointed under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or (Amended 18 of 2005 s. 48)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a liquidator, provisional liquidator or special manager appointed under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32). (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.leadIn: Where a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order takes any action—
