paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to property which is not realisable property, being action which he would be entitled to take if it were such property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: believing, and having reasonable grounds for believing, that he is entitled to take that action in relation to that property,

subsection.continued: he shall not be liable to any person in respect of any loss or damage resulting from his action except in so far as the loss or damage is caused by his negligence.

subsection.content: Any amount due in respect of the remuneration and expenses of a receiver so appointed shall, if no sum is available to be applied in payment of it under section 13(3), be paid by the prosecutor or, in a case where proceedings for a drug trafficking offence are not instituted, by the person on whose application the receiver was appointed.

An authorized officer may, for the purpose of an investigation into drug trafficking, apply to a court for an order under subsection (2) in relation to particular material or material of a particular description.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 23(10), the court may, if on such an application it is satisfied that the conditions in subsection (4) are fulfilled, make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that the person who appears to the court to be in possession or control of the material to which the application relates shall—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: produce the material to an authorized officer for him to take away; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: give an authorized officer access to it,

paragraph.continued: within such period as the order may specify;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that the person who appears to the court likely to come into possession or control of the material to which the application relates shall, when the person comes into possession or control of any such material—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: produce the material to an authorized officer for him to take away; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: give an authorized officer access to it,

paragraph.continued: within such period as the order may specify; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in terms both of paragraphs (a) and (b). (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 18)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (2), in so far as it is in terms of paragraph (b) of that subsection, shall cease to have effect upon the expiration of 3 months after the day on which the order is made, or upon the expiration of such lesser period, if any, as is specified in the order for the purpose, but nothing in this subsection shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affect any obligation incurred under that order prior to its expiration;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevent, in relation to the person required to comply with that order, any further order being made under that subsection in respect of that person (including before the expiration of that first-mentioned order). (Added 89 of 1995 s. 18)

subsection.content: The period to be specified in an order under subsection (2) shall be 7 days unless it appears to the court that a longer or shorter period would be appropriate in the particular circumstances of the application.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a specified person has carried on or has benefited from drug trafficking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the material to which the application relates—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is likely to be of substantial value (whether by itself or together with other material) to the investigation for the purpose of which the application is made; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: does not consist of or include items subject to legal privilege; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that it is in the public interest, having regard—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the benefit likely to accrue to the investigation if the material is obtained; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: to the circumstances under which the person—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: in possession or control of the material holds or controls it, as the case may be; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: likely to come into possession or control of the material will hold or control it, as the case may be, if he comes into such possession or control,

subparagraph.continued: as the case may be, (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 18)

paragraph.continued: that the material should be produced or that access to it should be given.

subsection.content: Where a court makes an order under subsection (2)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) in relation to material on any premises it may, on the same or a subsequent application of an authorized officer, order any person who appears to him to be entitled to grant entry to the premises to allow an authorized officer to enter the premises to obtain access to the material. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 18)

subsection.leadIn: Rules of court may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the discharge and variation of orders under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings relating to such orders.

subsection.leadIn: Where the material to which an application under this section relates consists of information contained in or accessible by means of any data equipment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under subsection (2)(a)(i) or (b)(i) shall have effect as an order to produce the material in a form in which it can be taken away and in which it is visible and legible; and (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 18)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under subsection (2)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) shall have effect as an order to give access to the material in a form in which it is visible and legible. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 18)

def.name: DataEquipment
def.leadIn: In subsection (7), data equipment (數據設備) means any equipment which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: automatically processes information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: automatically records or stores information;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: can be used to cause information to be automatically recorded, stored or otherwise processed on other equipment (wherever situated);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: can be used to retrieve information, whether the information is recorded or stored in the equipment itself or in other equipment (wherever situated).

subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not confer any right to production of, or access to, items subject to legal privilege;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall have effect notwithstanding any obligation as to secrecy or other restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by statute or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may be made in relation to material in the possession of a public body as defined in section 23.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may, for the purpose of an investigation into drug trafficking, apply to a court for a warrant under this section in relation to specified premises.

subsection.leadIn: On such application the court may issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter and search the premises if it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an order made under section 20 in relation to material on the premises has not been complied with; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the conditions in subsection (3) are fulfilled; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the conditions in subsection (4) are fulfilled.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(b) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a specified person has carried on or has benefited from drug trafficking; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the conditions in section 20(4)(b) and (c) are fulfilled in relation to any material on the premises; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that it would not be appropriate to make an order under that section in relation to the material because—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to produce the material; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant access to the material or entitled to grant entry to the premises on which the material is situated; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the investigation for the purposes of which the application is made might be seriously prejudiced unless an authorized officer could secure immediate access to the material.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(c) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a specified person has carried on or has benefited from drug trafficking; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is on the premises material relating to the specified person or to drug trafficking which is likely to be of substantial value (whether by itself or together with other material) to the investigation for the purpose of which the application is made, but that the material cannot at the time of the application be particularized; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with any person entitled to grant entry to the premises; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: entry to the premises will not be granted unless a warrant is produced; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the investigation for the purposes of which the application is made might be seriously prejudiced unless an authorized officer arriving at the premises could secure immediate entry to them.

subsection.content: Where an authorized officer has entered premises in the execution of a warrant issued under this section, he may seize and retain any material, other than items subject to legal privilege, which is likely to be of substantial value (whether by itself or together with other material) to the investigation for the purpose of which the warrant was issued.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who hinders or obstructs an authorized officer in the execution of a warrant issued under this section commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

subsection.content: Notwithstanding section 83 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1), but subject to this section, a warrant may be issued under this section authorizing entry to premises for the purpose of searching for or seizing material which is known or suspected to be journalistic material. (Added 88 of 1995 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may photograph or make copies of any material—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: produced or to which access is given under section 20; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: seized under section 21.

subsection.leadIn: In sections 20 and 21—
subsection.def: court (法庭) means the Court of First Instance and the District Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

def.name: ItemsSubjectToLegalPrivilege
def.leadIn: items subject to legal privilege (享有法律特權的品目) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: communications between a professional legal adviser and his client or any person representing his client or between such an adviser or his client or any such representative and any other person made in connection with or in contemplation of legal proceedings and for the purposes of such proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: items enclosed with or referred to in such communications and made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in connection with the giving of legal advice; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in connection with or in contemplation of legal proceedings and for the purposes of such proceedings,

def.name: Premises
def.leadIn: premises (房產) includes any place and, in particular, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any vehicle, vessel, aircraft, hovercraft or offshore structure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any tent or movable structure.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Disclosure of information held by public bodies

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), the Court of First Instance may, on an application by the prosecutor, order any material mentioned in subsection (3) which is in the possession of a public body to be produced to the Court of First Instance within such period as the Court of First Instance may specify.

subsection.leadIn: The power to make an order under subsection (1) is exercisable if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10(1) and 11(1) are exercisable by virtue of section 9(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those powers are exercisable by virtue of section 9(2) and the Court of First Instance has made a restraint or charging order which has not been discharged,

subsection.continued: but where the power to make an order under subsection (1) is exercisable by virtue only of paragraph (b), section 9(3) shall apply for the purposes of this section as it applies for the purposes of sections 10 and 11.

subsection.leadIn: The material referred to in subsection (1) is any material which—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: has been made by an officer of a public body in relation to the defendant or such a person; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is correspondence which passed between an officer of a public body and the defendant or such a person,

subsection.continued: and an order under that subsection may require the production of all such material or of a particular description of such material, being material in the possession of the body concerned.

subsection.content: An order under subsection (1) shall not require the production of any material unless it appears to the Court of First Instance that the material is likely to contain information that would facilitate the exercise of the powers conferred on the Court of First Instance by sections 10 to 12 or on a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order.

The Court of First Instance may by order authorize the disclosure to such a receiver of any material produced under subsection (1) or any part of such material; but the Court of First Instance shall not make an order under this subsection unless a reasonable opportunity has been given for an officer of the public body to make representations to the Court of First Instance.

Material disclosed in pursuance of an order under subsection (5) may, subject to any conditions contained in the order, be further disclosed for the purposes of the functions under this Ordinance of the receiver or the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may by order authorize the disclosure to an authorized officer of any material produced under subsection (1) or any part of such material; but the Court of First Instance shall not make an order under this subsection unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reasonable opportunity has been given for an officer of the public body to make representations to the Court of First Instance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the Court of First Instance that the material is likely to be of substantial value in exercising functions relating to drug trafficking.

subsection.content: Material disclosed in pursuance of an order under subsection (7) may, subject to any conditions contained in the order, be further disclosed for the purposes of functions relating to drug trafficking.

Material may be produced or disclosed in pursuance of this section notwithstanding any obligation as to secrecy or other restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by statute or otherwise.

An order under subsection (1) and, in the case of material in the possession of a public body, an order under section 20(2) may require any officer of the public body (whether named in the order or not) who may for the time being be in possession of the material concerned to comply with it, and such an order shall be served as if the proceedings were civil proceedings against the Government. (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)

def.name: PublicBody
def.leadIn: In this section public body (公共機構) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any Government department; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any body specified by the Chief Executive under subsection (12). (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may, by notice in the Gazette, specify a body to be a public body for the purposes of this section. (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)

Where, in relation to an investigation into drug trafficking, an order under section 20 has been made or has been applied for and has not been refused or a warrant under section 21 has been issued, a person who, knowing or suspecting that the investigation is taking place, makes any disclosure which is likely to prejudice the investigation commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings against a person for an offence under this section, it is a defence to prove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that he did not know or suspect that the disclosure was likely to prejudice the investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that he had lawful authority or reasonable excuse for making the disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

section.name: s24A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: court (法院) means the Court of First Instance and the District Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
exported (輸出), in relation to any property, includes the property being brought to any place in Hong Kong for the purpose of being exported;
seized property (經扣押的財產) means any property seized under section 52 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134) on the ground that it is suspected to be specified property;

def.name: SpecifiedProperty
def.leadIn: specified property (指明財產) means any property specified in Schedule 4—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being imported into or exported from Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has been used in drug trafficking; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is intended for use in drug trafficking;

section.def: working day (工作日) means any day other than a public holiday or a gale warning day within the meaning of the Judicial Proceedings (Adjournment During Gale Warnings) Ordinance (Cap. 62).

section.name: s24B
section.heading: Seized property may be detained
section.content: An authorized officer may, in accordance with the provisions of this Part, detain any seized property.

section.name: s24C
section.heading: Period for which seized property may be detained

subsection.content: Seized property shall not be detained for a period of more than 10 working days in the case of such property being imported into Hong Kong, or 7 working days in the case of such property being exported from Hong Kong, unless, before the expiration of that period, the continued detention of such property is authorized by an order under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: A court may, upon application made to it by an authorized officer, by order authorize the continued detention of seized property where it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that such property is specified property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: such detention of such property is justified while its origin or derivation is further investigated or consideration is given to the institution (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere) of proceedings—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: against any person in relation to an offence with which such property is connected; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: which may result in the forfeiture or other confiscation of such property.

subsection.leadIn: An order under subsection (2) shall authorize the continued detention of the seized property to which it relates for such period, not exceeding 3 months beginning with the date of the order, as is specified in the order and a court, upon application made to it by an authorized officer and if satisfied as to the matters referred to in subsection (2)(a) and (b), may thereafter from time to time by order authorize the further detention of such property but so that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no period of detention specified in an order under this subsection shall exceed 3 months beginning with the date of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total period of detention shall not exceed 2 years from the date of the order under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: At any time while seized property is being detained by an order under subsection (2) or (3) a court may direct its release if satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: on an application made by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person from whom it was seized;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a person by or on whose behalf it was being imported or exported; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a person who otherwise has an interest in it,

paragraph.continued: that there are no, or are no longer, any such grounds for its detention as are referred to in subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on an application made by an authorized officer, that its detention is no longer justified.

subsection.leadIn: If, at any time when any seized property is being detained by virtue of an order under subsection (2) or (3), proceedings are instituted (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against any person in relation to an offence with which such property is connected; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which may result in the forfeiture or other confiscation of such property,

subsection.continued: such property shall not be released until such proceedings have been concluded.

subsection.content: The Legislative Council may, by resolution, amend subsection (1) by substituting another period for any period specified therein.

subsection.leadIn: While any seized property is detained under section 24C(2) or (3), a court may, if satisfied on an application made by or on behalf of the Secretary for Justice that such property— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been used in drug trafficking; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is intended for use in drug trafficking,

subsection.continued: order, subject to subsection (2), the forfeiture of such property.

subsection.content: Where a court proposes to make an order under subsection (1) in respect of any seized property where paragraph (a) of that subsection is applicable, the court shall specify in the order so much, if any, of such property in respect of which the court is not satisfied that it directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking.
An order may be made under this section whether or not proceedings are brought against any person for an offence with which the seized property concerned is connected.
The standard of proof on an application under this section shall be on the balance of probabilities.

section.name: s24E
section.heading: Interest
section.content: Seized property which is money and which is detained in pursuance of an order under section 24C(2) or (3) shall, unless required as evidence of an offence, be held in an interest-bearing account and the interest accruing thereon shall be added to such property on its forfeiture or release.

subsection.content: An order under section 24C(2) shall provide for notice to be given to persons affected by the order.

subsection.leadIn: Provision may be made by rules of court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with respect to applications to any court under this Part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: with respect to the division, conversion or disposal of seized property for the purposes of satisfying an order under section 24D(1) to which it is subject where—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: section 24D(2) is applicable; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such property is not readily divisible for those purposes;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally with respect to the procedure under this Part before any court.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) is without prejudice to the generality of any existing power to make rules.

part.name: P5
part.heading: Prohibited Acts in relation to Proceeds of Drug Trafficking

section.name: s25
section.heading: Dealing with property known or believed to represent proceeds of drug trafficking

subsection.content: Subject to section 25A, a person commits an offence if, knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that any property in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking, he deals with that property.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings against a person for an offence under subsection (1), it is a defence to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he intended to disclose to an authorized officer such knowledge, suspicion or matter as is mentioned in section 25A(1) in relation to the act in contravention of subsection (1) concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is reasonable excuse for his failure to make disclosure in accordance with section 25A(2).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 14 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s25A
section.heading: Disclosure of knowledge or suspicion that property represents proceeds, etc. of drug trafficking

subsection.leadIn: Where a person knows or suspects that any property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was used in connection with; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is intended to be used in connection with,

subsection.continued: drug trafficking, he shall as soon as it is reasonable for him to do so disclose that knowledge or suspicion, together with any matter on which that knowledge or suspicion is based, to an authorized officer.

subsection.leadIn: If a person who has made a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) does any act in contravention of section 25(1) (whether before or after such disclosure), and the disclosure relates to that act, he does not commit an offence under that section if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that disclosure is made before he does that act and he does that act with the consent of an authorized officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that disclosure is made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: after he does that act;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on his initiative; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: as soon as it is reasonable for him to make it.

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure referred to in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be treated as a breach of any restriction upon the disclosure of information imposed by contract or by any enactment, rule of conduct or other provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not render the person who made it liable in damages for any loss arising out of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any act done or omitted to be done in relation to the property concerned in consequence of the disclosure.

subsection.content: In the case of a person who was in employment at the relevant time, this section shall have effect in relation to disclosures to the appropriate person in accordance with the procedure established by his employer for the making of such disclosures as it has effect in relation to disclosures to an authorized officer.

A person commits an offence if, knowing or suspecting that a disclosure has been made under subsection (1) or (4), he discloses to any other person any matter which is likely to prejudice any investigation which might be conducted following that first-mentioned disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings against a person for an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence to prove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that he did not know or suspect that the disclosure concerned was likely to be prejudicial in the way referred to in that subsection; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that he had lawful authority or reasonable excuse for making that disclosure.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (5) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.leadIn: Information obtained under or by virtue of a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) may be disclosed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by any authorized officer to the Department of Justice, the Hong Kong Police Force, the Customs and Excise Department, the Immigration Department, and the Independent Commission Against Corruption, for the purpose of combating drug trafficking; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by any authorized officer to the authorities or persons responsible for investigating or preventing drug trafficking, or handling the disclosure of knowledge or suspicion on property relating to drug trafficking, of any place outside Hong Kong which the authorized officer thinks fit, for the purpose of combating drug trafficking. (Added 21 of 2004 s. 24)

subsection.content: Subsection (9) is without prejudice to any other right to disclose information obtained under or by virtue of a disclosure referred to in subsection (1) that may exist apart from subsection (9). (Added 21 of 2004 s. 24)

section.name: s26
section.heading: Restriction on revealing disclosure under section 25A

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), no witness in any civil or criminal proceedings shall be obliged—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to reveal the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to answer any question if the answer would lead, or would tend to lead, to the revealing of any fact or matter referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not apply in any proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an offence under section 25 or 25A or this section; or (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 22)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the court is of the opinion that justice cannot fully be done between the parties without revealing the disclosure or the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (4), (5) and (6), no person shall publish or broadcast any information so as to reveal or suggest—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a disclosure was made under section 25A(1) or (4); or (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 22)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the identity of any person as the person making the disclosure.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: includes a report of any civil or criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not include information published for statistical purposes by, or under the authority of, the Government.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) shall not apply in respect of proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against the person making the disclosure for an offence under section 25 or 25A; or (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 22)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for an offence under this section.

subsection.content: The court or a magistrate may, if satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so, by order dispense with the requirements of subsection (3) to such extent as may be specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: If information is published or broadcast in contravention of subsection (3), each of the following persons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of publication as part of a newspaper or periodical publication, any proprietor, editor, publisher and distributor thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a publication otherwise than as part of a newspaper or periodical publication, any person who publishes it and any person who distributes it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a broadcast, any person who broadcasts the information and, if the information is contained in a programme, any person who transmits or provides the programme and any person having functions in relation to the programme corresponding to those of the editor of a newspaper or periodical publication,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2019)

subsection.content: Proceedings for an offence under this section shall not be instituted except with the consent of the Secretary for Justice. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: publish (出版) means publish in writing.

subsection.leadIn: If an investigation is begun against a person for a drug trafficking offence or offences and any of the following circumstances occur, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no proceedings are instituted against that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings are instituted against that person but do not result in his conviction for any drug trafficking offence (including any proceedings referred to in section 3(1)(a)(ii) where no confiscation order is made against that person); (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 24)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.leadIn: that person absconds after proceedings are instituted against him and subsequently—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he ceases to be an absconder; and

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: those proceedings are continued or reinstituted but do not result in his conviction for any drug trafficking offence; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: those proceedings are not continued or reinstituted within a reasonable period after it is known to the Secretary for Justice that he has ceased to be an absconder; or (Added 89 of 1995 s. 24. Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings are instituted against that person and he is convicted of one or more drug trafficking offences, but—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the conviction or convictions concerned are quashed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is granted a pardon in respect of the conviction or convictions concerned,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on application by a person who held property which was realisable property (or, in the case of such a person who has died, his personal representative on his behalf), order compensation to be paid by the Government to the applicant if, having regard to all the circumstances, it considers it appropriate to make such an order. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 24)

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (1) unless it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3A), that there has been some serious default on the part of any person concerned in the investigation or prosecution of the offence or offences concerned; and (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 24)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the applicant has suffered loss in consequence of anything done in relation to the property by or in pursuance of an order of the Court of First Instance under sections 10 to 12.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3A), the Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (1) in any case where it appears to the Court of First Instance that the investigation would have been continued, or the proceedings would have been instituted or continued, as the case may be, if the serious default had not occurred. (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 24)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Subsections (2)(a) and (3) shall not apply to any case to which subsection (1)(ba) is applicable. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 24)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to subsection (1), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a disclosure is made by any person in accordance with section 25A(2) in relation to any property; (Amended 89 of 1995 s. 24)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in consequence of the disclosure and for the purposes of an investigation or prosecution in respect of a drug trafficking offence or offences any act is done or omitted to be done in relation to that property; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no proceedings are instituted against any person in respect of that offence or offences or no order is made by the Court of First Instance under section 10 or 11 in relation to that property,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on application by a person who held the property, order compensation to be paid by the Government to the applicant if, having regard to all the circumstances, it considers it appropriate to make such an order.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under section (4) unless it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there has been some serious default on the part of any person concerned in the investigation or prosecution of the offence or offences concerned and that, but for that default, the act or omission referred to in subsection (4)(b) would not have occurred; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant has, in consequence of the act or omission referred to in subsection (4)(b), suffered loss in relation to the property.

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to either subsection (1) or (4), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any property is seized under section 52 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134) on the ground that it is suspected to be specified property within the meaning of Part IVA; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subsequently, none of the following events occurs—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the property is forfeited under section 24D;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: proceedings are instituted (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere)—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: against any person in relation to an offence with which the property is connected; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: which may result in the forfeiture or other confiscation of the property,

subsection.continued: the Court of First Instance may, on application by a person who held the property, order compensation to be paid by the Government to the applicant if, having regard to all the circumstances, it considers it appropriate to make such an order. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 24)

subsection.name: 5B
subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance shall not order compensation to be paid under subsection (5A) unless it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there has been some serious default on the part of any person concerned with the seizure or detention of the property concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant has, in consequence of such seizure or detention, suffered loss in relation to the property. (Added 89 of 1995 s. 24)

subsection.content: The amount of compensation to be paid under this section shall be such as the Court of First Instance thinks just in all the circumstances of the case.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may, with the approval of the Legislative Council, by order— (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct in relation to a country, territory or place outside Hong Kong designated by the order (a designated country) that this Ordinance as modified in the order shall apply to external confiscation orders and to proceedings which have been or are to be instituted in the designated country and may result in an external confiscation order being made there; (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3, 26 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: make—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: such provision in connection with the taking of action in the designated country with a view to satisfying a confiscation order; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such provision as to evidence or proof of any matter for the purposes of this section and section 29; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: such incidental, consequential and transitional provision,

paragraph.continued: as appears to him to be expedient; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without prejudice to the generality of this subsection, direct that in such circumstances as may be specified proceeds arising out of action taken in the designated country with a view to satisfying a confiscation order and which are retained there shall nevertheless be treated as reducing the amount payable under the order to such extent as may be specified.

subsection.content: An order under this section may make different provision for different cases or classes of case.
The power to make an order under this section includes power to modify this Ordinance in such a way as to confer power on a person to exercise a discretion.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: An order under this section shall not operate, or be construed, to prevent a designated country from making a request under the Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Ordinance (Cap. 525), including a request under section 27 of that Ordinance. (Added 87 of 1997 s. 36)

subsection.leadIn: In this section and section 29—

def.name: ExternalConfiscationOrder
def.leadIn: external confiscation order (外地沒收令) means an order made by a court in a designated country for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: recovering (including forfeiting and confiscating)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: payments or other rewards received in connection with drug trafficking or their value;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: property derived or realised, directly or indirectly, from payments or other rewards received in connection with drug trafficking or the value of such property; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: property used or intended to be used in connection with drug trafficking or the value of such property; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: depriving a person of a pecuniary advantage obtained in connection with drug trafficking,

def.continued: and whether the proceedings which gave rise to that order are criminal or civil in nature, and whether those proceedings are in the form of proceedings against a person or property; (Replaced 87 of 1997 s. 36)

subsection.def: modifications (修改) includes additions, alterations and omissions.

subsection.leadIn: On an application made by or on behalf of the government of a designated country, the Court of First Instance may register an external confiscation order made there if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is satisfied that at the time of registration the order is in force and not subject to appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is satisfied, where any person against whom, or in relation to whose property, the order is made does not appear in the proceedings, that he received notice of the proceedings, in accordance with the law of the designated country, in sufficient time to enable him to defend them; and (Replaced 89 of 1995 s. 26)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that enforcing the order in Hong Kong would not be contrary to the interests of justice.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings by way of discharging or setting aside a judgment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for a new trial or a stay of execution.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance shall cancel the registration of an external confiscation order if it appears to the Court of First Instance that the order has been satisfied by payment of the amount due under it or by the person against whom it was made serving imprisonment in default of payment or by any other means.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Evidence of corresponding law
section.content: Section 43 of the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance (Cap. 134) shall apply in relation to proceedings under this Ordinance as it applies in relation to proceedings for an offence under that Ordinance.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order, amend Schedule 1, 2 or 3. (Amended 15 of 1999 s. 3)
The Legislative Council may, by resolution, amend Schedule 4.
